doc.field: Overlooking all of Rio de Janeiro is the stature of Christ the Redeemer which is about 120 feet high. This beautiful stature was completed around 1931.

brazil peru uros laketiticaca argentina rio inca cuzco riodejaneiro lima christtheredeemer copacabana machupicchu sacsayhuaman copa casarosada santelmo puno tambomachay ollantaytambo boliva iguassufalls urosindians witchesmarket quatimundi racchi cemeteryofrecoleta motherearthwomb
Next stop was Rio! Beautiful and world known for it's famous scenery. This shot was taken as we were on our way to see the stature of Christ the Redeemer.

This stature of Christ stands near Sacsayhuaman and Tambomachay overlooking Cuzco. Beautiful Scene.

Yep, that's it, the iconic photo of Rio with Sugarloaf Mountain in the distance.

Frontal view of the stature as we walked around it and were amazed at it's construction.

If you are not in Rio when the real event takes place, well, you still have to go to one of the shows. Great Fun!

The first car offers a great view of the Christ the Redeemer Stature which is actually very far away.

The finale to the show! Rio de Janeiro ROCKS!

This is it, our flight leaves tonight. Time enough for one more coconut drink by the Ipanema Beach. Our trip to South America was simply amazing! From the high Andes in Peru to the Rio Beaches we had the time of our life.

As we approached the top of Sugarloaf Mountain we turned around and here is the view looking back on parts of Rio.

This wonderful lady was making cloth rugs while dressed in typical Peruvian clothing. She was very nice and we had a great time with her.

Great shot close up to some of the Iguassu falls. There's a whole lot of water going over that edge.

The Inca used very interesting building techniques, most not understood, and interesting building materials. Some of the stones used at Racchi are actually volcanic.

As we continue up the mountain climb at Machu Picchu we look back and over to the Andes. Beautiful!

Shot taken inside of the Plaza de Armas Cathedral in Cuzco. This Cathedral was built on the ruins of an Inca Palace. That's an Inca wall and that smile is from chewing Coca leaves, to fight the altitude sickness of course.
